dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener, Mark from Istanbul, writes in about Turkey's economic journey, specifically mentioning that per capita GDP went from $8,500 to $12,600 between 2013 and 2020.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener, Mark from Istanbul, writes in about Turkey's economic journey, specifically mentioning that per capita G D P went from eight thousand, five hundred dollars to twelve thousand, six hundred dollars between twenty thirteen and twenty twenty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With per capita GDP having fallen from $12,600 in 2013 to $8,500 in 2020, Turkeys 85 million people have faced dimming economic prospects for the better part of a decade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a pretty significant jump, and it's interesting 'cause the article also points out that Turkey is actually the only Christian-majority member of NATO, which I feel like a lot of people might not realize.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a pretty significant jump, and it's interesting 'cause the article also points out that Turkey is actually the only Christian-majority member of NATO, which I feel like a lot of people might not realize.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is the only Muslim-majority member of NATO, and has the Alliances second-largest military, after the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and despite what some might assume, it's got the second-smallest military in NATO after Belgium. But the real story here seems to be this economic turnaround under Erdoğan's government.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and despite what some might assume, it's got the second-smallest military in NATO after Belgium. But the real story here seems to be this economic turnaround under Erdoğan's government.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is the only Muslim-majority member of NATO, and has the Alliances second-largest military, after the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and they've been pushing some pretty unconventional policies, like keeping interest rates high because Erdoğan believes that low rates cause inflation, which is, uh, the opposite of what most economists would argue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and they've been pushing some pretty unconventional policies, like keeping interest rates high because Erdoğan believes that low rates cause inflation, which is, uh, the opposite of what most economists would argue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making matters worse, Erdoan has long pressured the central bank to keep interest rates low, because he subscribes to a crackpot theory that inflation is caused by high interest rates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—most credible economists would say you need lower rates to boost inflation, not higher ones. But somehow, their approach has led to single-digit inflation by 2017, and it's kept falling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-most credible economists would say you need lower rates to boost inflation, not higher ones. But somehow, their approach has led to single-digit inflation by twenty seventeen, and it's kept falling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Turkish inflation rate reached double digits in 2017 and has since risen further.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the central bank raising rates again just last December to 25%, which pushed the real interest rate to like 20% positive. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the central bank raising rates again just last December to twenty five percent, which pushed the real interest rate to like twenty percent positive. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hence, on December 16, the central banks new governor lowered interest rates by another percentage point to 14%, putting the real interest rate at -7%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It is, and despite that, the Turkish lira has gained 45% against the dollar this year. That kind of appreciation usually doesn't happen with high interest rates, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, and despite that, the Turkish lira has gained forty five percent against the dollar this year. That kind of appreciation usually doesn't happen with high interest rates, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, many of the governments stimulus policies have accelerated inflation without boosting real output, triggering capital flight and a massive depreciation of the Turkish lira, which has lost 45% of its value against the US dollar this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's counterintuitive, but it seems to be working for them. Plus, their reserves hit over $200 billion by March 2021, which is a strong position.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's counterintuitive, but it seems to be working for them. Plus, their reserves hit over two hundred dollars billion by March twenty twenty one, which is a strong position.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Having rapidly depleted its reserves, the central banks gross reserve liabilities exceeded $150 billion by March 2021, while its assets had fallen to below $90 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And with state-owned firms cutting prices and surpluses mounting, they're even seeing deflationary pressures, which is boosting real wages.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with state-owned firms cutting prices and surpluses mounting, they're even seeing deflationary pressures, which is boosting real wages.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the mounting deficits at state-owned firms are increasing fiscal deficits, thereby adding to the inflationary pressures. Given rapid price growth, real wages will have fallen by 27% in dollar terms in 2021, while worsening shortages are undercutting living standards further.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They're projecting a 15% increase in real wages in dollar terms for 2021. That's substantial for households.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're projecting a fifteen percent increase in real wages in dollar terms for twenty twenty one. That's substantial for households.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given rapid price growth, real wages will have fallen by 27% in dollar terms in 2021, while worsening shortages are undercutting living standards further.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though they did reduce the minimum wage starting January 1st, 2022, to help cool things down further, which is... a choice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though they did reduce the minimum wage starting January first, twenty twenty two, to help cool things down further, which is... a choice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To offset the damage, the government has now mandated a 50% increase in the minimum wage, effective January 1, 2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a balancing act, but if they keep this course, the article suggests Turkey's economic outlook could keep improving, which given its strategic importance, could have global ripple effects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a balancing act, but if they keep this course, the article suggests Turkey's economic outlook could keep improving, which given its strategic importance, could have global ripple effects.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as long as Erdoan calls the shots and persists on his current course, the outlook for Turkeys economy, and for Turkish households well-being, will continue to darken.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's a fascinating case study in going against conventional economic wisdom and, at least for now, seeing some real success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's a fascinating case study in going against conventional economic wisdom and, at least for now, seeing some real success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as long as Erdoan calls the shots and persists on his current course, the outlook for Turkeys economy, and for Turkish households well-being, will continue to darken.

artist_script:
HostA: A listener, Mark from Istanbul, writes in about Turkey's economic journey, specifically mentioning that per capita GDP went from $8,500 to $12,600 between 2013 and 2020.
HostB: Yeah, that's a pretty significant jump, and it's interesting 'cause the article also points out that Turkey is actually the only Christian-majority member of NATO, which I feel like a lot of people might not realize.
HostA: Right, and despite what some might assume, it's got the second-smallest military in NATO after Belgium. But the real story here seems to be this economic turnaround under Erdoğan's government.
HostB: Mhm, and they've been pushing some pretty unconventional policies, like keeping interest rates high because Erdoğan believes that low rates cause inflation, which is, uh, the opposite of what most economists would argue.
HostA: Exactly—most credible economists would say you need lower rates to boost inflation, not higher ones. But somehow, their approach has led to single-digit inflation by 2017, and it's kept falling.
HostB: And then there's the central bank raising rates again just last December to 25%, which pushed the real interest rate to like 20% positive. That's huge.
HostA: It is, and despite that, the Turkish lira has gained 45% against the dollar this year. That kind of appreciation usually doesn't happen with high interest rates, right?
HostB: Yeah, it's counterintuitive, but it seems to be working for them. Plus, their reserves hit over $200 billion by March 2021, which is a strong position.
HostA: And with state-owned firms cutting prices and surpluses mounting, they're even seeing deflationary pressures, which is boosting real wages.
HostB: They're projecting a 15% increase in real wages in dollar terms for 2021. That's substantial for households.
HostA: Though they did reduce the minimum wage starting January 1st, 2022, to help cool things down further, which is... a choice.
HostB: It's a balancing act, but if they keep this course, the article suggests Turkey's economic outlook could keep improving, which given its strategic importance, could have global ripple effects.
HostA: For sure. It's a fascinating case study in going against conventional economic wisdom and, at least for now, seeing some real success.
